item.dc:creator: abelcheung
item.description:
Akismet widget shows a string impossible to localize: "$count spam comments blocked by Akismet", only that this strings is chopped up by N tags (I don't know how to count). Probably my word is strong, since it should have been the greatest design ever, otherwise it would not be in source code.

Attached patch makes this string translatable -- IMHO my version is utter crap, just that it becomes translatable.

item.title: Ticket #4251 (Small error in get_posts not?) reopened
item.dc:creator: momo360modena
item.description:
Not a SQL problem... just double $query ... 

	$query ="SELECT DISTINCT * FROM $wpdb->posts " ;
	$query .= ( empty( $category ) ? "" : ", $wpdb->post2cat " );
	$query .= ( empty( $meta_key ) ? "" : ", $wpdb->postmeta " );
	$query .= " WHERE (post_type = 'post' AND post_status = 'publish') $exclusions $inclusions ";
	$query .= ( empty( $category ) ? "" : "AND ($wpdb->posts.ID = $wpdb->post2cat.post_id AND $wpdb->post2cat.category_id = " . $category. ") " );
	$query .= ( empty( $meta_key ) | empty($meta_value)  ? "" : " AND ($wpdb->posts.ID = $wpdb->postmeta.post_id AND $wpdb->postmeta.meta_key = '$meta_key' AND $wpdb->postmeta.meta_value = '$meta_value' )" );
	$query .= " GROUP BY $wpdb->posts.ID ORDER BY " . $orderby . " " . $order . " LIMIT " . $offset . ',' . $numberposts;
	$query  = "SELECT DISTINCT * FROM $wpdb->posts ";
	$query .= empty( $category ) ? '' : ", $wpdb->post2cat ";
	$query .= empty( $meta_key ) ? '' : ", $wpdb->postmeta ";
	$query .= " WHERE 1=1 ";
	$query .= empty( $post_type ) ? '' : "AND post_type = '$post_type' ";
	$query .= empty( $post_status ) ? '' : "AND post_status = '$post_status' ";
	$query .= "$exclusions $inclusions " ;

item.description: You can't call a function before it is defined, namely status_header(). Will create fatal errors.

item.title: Ticket #4084 (add_query_arg urldecodes passed values but doesn't re-encode them.) updated
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description: Just so you're aware, this did break another useful function of add_query_arg, which was in easily adding arguments to param style arguments, like for wp_list_pages(). I was using it, for example, to quickly append rewrite rule query entries. So, for those who were doing a similar thing and specifically didn't want things urlencoding, the workaround is to rawurlencode the argument you pass to add_query_arg and then urldecode the whole result.

item.title: Ticket #1476 (WordPress Update Notification) updated
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description: If you're going to parse a response in JS, you might want to consider JSON as your transfer format. It is possible to parse XML, but far easier to parse JSON. (One line in fact, if you just eval it). If security is a concern, I'm sure jQuery has JSON parsing functionality - Prototype certainly does. And if the WordPress server is running PHP 5.2, there is a built-in JSON extension for creating it as well...

item.title: Ticket #4247 (Add tag import utility for Simple Tagging plugin) updated
item.dc:creator: Nazgul
item.description: Keywords changed

item.title: Ticket #4248 (Workaround for XML-RPC bug in PHP 5.2.2) reopened
item.dc:creator: Nazgul
item.description:
I'd like to champion this ticket for 2.2 inclusion.

Why:

  • By the time 2.3 ships most hosters will still run PHP 4.x or live on the edge and run on >= 5.2.3. This fix will not help many people any more then, because they're not affected.
  • When 2.2 is released 5.2.2 is used by the people living on the edge. Therefore this fix actually helps a lot of people.

item.title: Ticket #3886 (wrong server protocol for HTTP/1.0 requests resulting in uninterpreted ...) updated
item.dc:creator: azza-bazoo
item.description:
I like this patch, but two nitpicks:

  • there's no need to trim() the SERVER_PROTOCOL value
  • If the protocol is unrecognised, it's safer to fall back to HTTP/1.0 than HTTP/1.1 -- wrongly assuming 1.1 was the original cause of this bug, after all.

item.title: Ticket #1476 (WordPress Update Notification) updated
item.dc:creator: rob1n
item.description:
Status changed

A "script."

  • WP: Load Dashboard, makes AJAX call to rpc.wordpress.org (or whatever). Could be run through another local PHP file to cache it in the DB, but I don't think it's needed. The request has GET or POST variables (probably GET) such as current, which has the current version.
  • RPC: Compare $_GETcurrent? with the current version, most likely using PHP's version_compare() (if we do the RPC in PHP). If it's fine, then return an XML response with <status>0</status> or something. If it's not up to date, then <status>1</status> <latest>2.3.1</latest> <type>critical/major/minor</type>.
  • WP: Use JS magic to parse the XML response (I know this is doable somehow). Based on what's returned, show an i18ned message in the Dashboard alerting the user to such, and provide a download link to ​http://wp.org/latest.tar.gz and ​http://wp.org/latest.zip

I'll work on this in the next few days.

item.description:
Owner, Milestone changed

I'm thinking we should fix this. Hosts, at least in my experience, aren't really known to upgrade when a new release comes out, at least right away. Besides, I don't think it hurts fixed versions of PHP, does it?
